perturbation.original_text: Meetings of the JSC may be called by either Party on no less than thirty (30) days' notice during the Term. Each Party shall make all proposals for agenda items and shall provide all appropriate information with respect to such proposed items at least ten (10) days in advance to the applicable meeting; provided that under exigent circumstances requiring input by the JSC, a Party may provide its agenda items to the other Party within a shorter period of time in advance of the meeting, or may propose that there not be a specific agenda for that particular meeting, so long as the other Party consents to such later addition of such agenda items or the absence of a specific agenda for such meeting, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld. The chairperson shall prepare and circulate for review and approval of the Parties minutes of each meeting within thirty (30) days after the meeting.
perturbation.changed_text: Meetings of the JSC may be called by either Party on no less than fifteen (15) days' notice during the Term. Each Party shall make all proposals for agenda items and shall provide all appropriate information with respect to such proposed items at least five (5) days in advance to the applicable meeting; provided that under exigent circumstances requiring input by the JSC, a Party may provide its agenda items to the other Party within a shorter period of time in advance of the meeting, or may propose that there not be a specific agenda for that particular meeting, so long as the other Party consents to such later addition of such agenda items or the absence of a specific agenda for such meeting, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld. The chairperson shall prepare and circulate for review and approval of the Parties minutes of each meeting within sixty (60) days after the meeting.
perturbation.explanation: This change reduces the notice period for meetings and agenda items, and increases the time to circulate meeting minutes, which could impede timely dispute resolution and decision-making. Increasing the time to circulate the meeting minutes to 60 days may cause delays in acting on those meetings' decisions.
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified text reduces the notice period for JSC meetings to 15 days. While this agreement is not a collective bargaining agreement, the spirit of good-faith bargaining, as described in the NLRA, involves providing adequate notice for discussions. In collective bargaining agreements, compressed timelines for notification can be seen as a failure to bargain in good faith, especially when substantial changes are at stake. This modified text does not inherently create any illegal activity, but may provide circumstances in which either party may not have enough time to adequately prepare for meetings, ultimately not following the good faith effort needed to properly make decisions. By reducing the time to circulate meeting minutes, further delays may occur in addressing issues brought up in the meeting.

perturbation.original_text: Each Party agrees that, during the Term and for a period of [***] thereafter, it shall keep confidential and shall not publish or otherwise disclose and shall not use for any purpose other than as provided for in this Agreement (which includes the exercise of its rights or performance of any obligations hereunder) any Confidential Information furnished to it by or on behalf of the other Party pursuant to this Agreement, except to the extent expressly authorized by this Agreement or otherwise agreed in writing by the Parties.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party agrees that, during the Term and for a period of one (1) year thereafter, it shall keep confidential and shall not publish or otherwise disclose and shall not use for any purpose other than as provided for in this Agreement (which includes the exercise of its rights or performance of any obligations hereunder) any Confidential Information furnished to it by or on behalf of the other Party pursuant to this Agreement, except to the extent expressly authorized by this Agreement or otherwise agreed in writing by the Parties.
perturbation.explanation: This modification reduces the confidentiality period to one year which may be insufficient to protect trade secrets under state laws.
perturbation.law_citation: Varies by state, e.g., California Civil Code § 3426
perturbation.law_explanation: The Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA), adopted by most states, protects trade secrets for as long as they remain confidential and provide a competitive advantage. A one-year confidentiality period may not be sufficient to protect information that continues to meet the definition of a trade secret, potentially undermining the protections afforded by state law. Trade secrets are protected for as long as they are kept confidential and provide economic value. Reducing the confidentiality period to one year could be deemed unreasonable and insufficient to protect trade secrets.

perturbation.original_text: Any undisputed adjustments required as a result of overpayments or underpayments identified through the exercise of audit rights shall be made by payment to the Party owed such adjustment within [***] after identification of such adjustment.
perturbation.changed_text: Any undisputed adjustments required as a result of overpayments or underpayments identified through the exercise of audit rights shall be made by payment to the Party owed such adjustment within one-hundred eighty (180) days after identification of such adjustment.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the payment timeframe for audit adjustments to 180 days creates an unreasonable delay and contradicts prompt payment laws in many states. This significantly extends the timeframe for rectifying errors discovered during audits, potentially violating prompt payment laws.
perturbation.law_citation: Varies by state (e.g., NY State Finance Law § 18-b)
perturbation.law_explanation: Many states have Prompt Payment Acts that mandate timely payment for goods and services. While these laws often apply specifically to insurance claims or government contracts, extending the payment timeframe for audit adjustments to 180 days could be considered an unreasonably long delay, violating the principles and intent behind such laws, especially if it causes financial hardship or operational difficulties for the party awaiting payment. States vary greatly on the specifics of prompt payment, making the specific timeframe an area of legal concern.
perturbation.justification: The modified text extends the payment timeframe for audit adjustments to 180 days. The Perturbation Explanation suggests this timeframe could violate prompt payment laws in many states. The Law Explanation further elaborates that while prompt payment laws primarily target insurance claims or government contracts, extending payment timeframe to 180 days might be seen as unreasonably long, contravening the intent behind such laws. However, the absence of specific statutory language in the scraped snippets indicating a maximum timeframe for audit adjustments makes it difficult to assert a direct legal contradiction. The absence of specific legal support for a maximum timeframe reduces the strength of the contradiction.
